critique: This executive order extends the provisions of a previous order (EO 9177) to the Atomic Energy Commission, granting it certain powers related to internal management during the post-war period. The order references the First War Powers Act of 1941, indicating a focus on national security and government efficiency in a time of potential crisis (even though the war was over, the Cold War was beginning). There's no explicit mention of immigration, civil liberties, or social issues. The order seems to centralize power within the executive branch by expanding the authority of the Atomic Energy Commission. It also appears to involve government intervention in economic matters by granting the commission powers previously held by various secretaries and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Given the context of the time, this is likely related to managing resources and production related to atomic energy.
